metadata.name: Future Echoes #161
metadata.description:
Future Echoes is a Generative Art experiment showing how a minute change in initial conditions can give rise to vastly different outcomes.

Created using pure JavaScript, without external libraries.

:: STYLES ::

- Pencil ----------- 68.5%
- Chalk ------------ 16%
- Biro ------------- 8%
- Error ------------ 4%
- Blueprints ------- 2%
- Final Warning ---- 1%
- Neon ------------- 0.5%


:: INSTRUCTIONS ::

- Add ?fullScreen=true to the url to render at full screen size
- To download the image in PNG format, press [s].

metadata.name: Loom #403
metadata.description:
A unique sketch of an imaginary weave. Color palette inspired by the great works of Anni Albers, Gunta Stölzl, Sophie Taeuber-Arp, or Hilma af Klint.

Experimental genesis token on fxhash made with p5.js and a custom shader.

Original artwork by Andreas Rau · Oslo, 2021

metadata.name: Hyperspacers #333
metadata.description:
Ancient creatures from deep space who can travel infinite great distances in hyperspace in an instant. They bring the seeds of life to remote corners of various galaxies.

This drawing is created with many thousands of strokes using pure javascript.

metadata.name: Errance #31
metadata.description:
Errance - an exploration of abstract and digital glitch fusion. The algorithm crafts the concept and structure, while randomness navigates the detailed textures, exploring the interplay between systematic design and the unforeseen aspects of randomness. Errance represents a journey of discovery, one without a defined endpoint, capturing the unexpected and fortuitous outcomes that emerge as algorithms navigate freely, leaving a trail of unique and unpredictable patterns.

Best experienced in live mode at high resolution, the outputs vary significantly due to multiple features, occasionally favouring a slightly asymmetric balance. Under the hood, the algorithm employs a combination of recursive functions, 3D primitives, and multiple textures derived from trigonometric and noise functions using p5.js. Last but not least, during rendering, the outputs are enhanced by one of several versions of a GLSL shader.

In live mode:
-press 1 to save a 2K-resolution PNG copy.
-press 2 for a 4K-resolution PNG copy.
-press 3 to render a version without passepartout.
-press 4 for a 2k-resolution PNG copy without passepartout.
-press 5 for a 4k-resolution PNG copy without passepartout.

metadata.name: Very Large Array #15
metadata.description: Very Large Array is a generative token by Leander Herzog. It creates one very large array to generate both visuals and audio. Made with javascript, webgl and the web audio api.

metadata.name: ribbon #19
metadata.description:
a grayscale composition with a cloth-like shape as a subject

made in p5.js

metadata.name: Anachronous #263
metadata.description:
This project is about the exploration of chaotic structures created with lines and blurry silhouettes. They work together to make the shapes emerge without revealing them completely and create dark and light areas that compose a feeling of depth and weight to the scene.

Some pieces are chaotic, some more ordered. Some have strong compositions, some don't. By zooming in on the details we can let our mind wander and start seeing shapes.

Best experienced in full-screen.

Press S to take a screenshot
Press M to take a high resolution screenshot
Press H to take a higher resolution screenshot (may not work for some devices)

WARNING: Project is using webgl, it may not work on some older devices.

Original artwork by William Watkins · Lyon, 2022

metadata.name: First Ignition #247
metadata.description: Many various shapes create chaos.

metadata.name: Metamorphose One #56
metadata.description:
Analog film photography, developed by hand, merged and overlayed in multiple exposures by code.

Collaboration by roman drits (@romandrits) and muradon (@muradon13), 2022.

metadata.name: L-2D CA #46
metadata.description:
Audiovisual architecture of a two dimensional cellular automation. An initial randomisation process is followed by a layering ritual. Time = space: cell states are locked into their corresponding positions on the elevation axis.

Touch to listen.

metadata.name: Turbulence #432
metadata.description:
Swirly shapes are rendered by passes of poisson samples of a warped noise field. The noise shifts with each pass, creating a layered effect. 

Dense editions may take over 2 minutes to draw fully.

Viewing in desktop Chrome is recommended for the best results.

Press ’s’ to save a screenshot. Image size is 928x1200px
Press ’p’ to pause/resume at any time during the drawing.

Add '&size=#' to the end of the live view URL to render a not 1:1 variation of your edition at a resolution up to 3,000 px.

Common:
- 43 set palettes plus many more with combinations
- 3 color distribution methods
- 50/50 dark
- 50/50 monochrome with bright highlights 
- 3 drawing styles: lines, points, colored pencils
- 5 noises effects: full screen, distance from center, distance from bottom, horizontal center, vertical center, random circles, 3,5, or 7 horizontal and vertical bars
- Poisson point distribution based on set layers or the noise value

Rare
- 15% chance of a dark monochrome with gold strands

Copyright (c) 2022 Matt Perkins, hello@mattperkins.me, @nudoru on Twitter. Licensed under CC BY-NC-SA 4.0, see LICENSE.txt for more information.

metadata.name: DON'T THINK #390
metadata.description: WHAT YOU SEE IS WHAT YOU SEE

metadata.name: Diamond Fractal Fire #46
metadata.description:
Diamond Fractal Fire interposes recursively generated poetry with similarly recursive fractal imagery. Each text (unique for each mint, but always 20 sentences in length) is generated by a custom context-free grammar algorithm, fed with lists of words selected by the creator. The fractal pattern in each edition is a variation on a Koch snowflake fractal, one of the earliest fractals described by mathematicians. These fractals grow over time at varying rates, and pulse with varying color ranges using Perlin noise, eventually filling the screen.


Push `h` to save high resolution PNG and JPG images of the complete fractal pattern (takes a moment to process)
Push `s` to save PNG and JPG images of the current browser view (with current browser window dimensions and resolution)
Push `v` to begin recording canvas as a video (with current browser window dimensions), then push `v` again to save the video
Push `f` to toggle fullscreen mode
Push `p` to toggle zoom pause
Push `r` to toggle zoom reverse
Push `c` to toggle color shift pause
Push `l` to toggle low resolution mode (improves framerate)


The animation is somewhat computationally expensive, and so it runs best on contemporary laptop and desktop computers. Mobile devices and older computers may experience low frame rates. Captured video quality may vary depending on compute and browser limitations. The animation is responsive (it will adapt to any screen or window size), and resizing your browser window also will restart the animation.

Color floors and variances represent ranges for Hue using a Hue/Saturation/Brightness (HSB) color model. Velocities represent (subtle) zoom speed differences. Noise increment and start values affect the rate and variation of color shifts.

In addition to the author's code, Diamond Fractal Fire relies on the p5.js library.

metadata.name: The Infinite Equation of Us #192
metadata.description:
until we meet again
in that space we've always occupied
timeless, crystallized
beyond the tick of clocks.
where every goodbye is just a pause...
in the infinite equation of us

metadata.name: Transition: Multidimensional #60
metadata.description:
The world is always and has always been in constant transition. Transitions have created and destroyed everything. Understanding and living with transitions is fundamental to being in the universe.

Transition is not one-dimensional. It is not just a move from A to B, but rather a constant shifting between A to F to % to 9 to AA to €. It is multi-faceted and multi-dimensional. This implies that binaries are merely imagined.

With this piece, I explore the idea of transitions being multidimensional by using shapes which progressively increase in edge count in all manner of ways. 

You’ll witness transitions that happen slowly, quickly, in fits and starts, and chaotically.

You’ll find transitions placed in circles, grids, towers, spirals, and more.

You’ll see transitions in multiple color schemes including inverted versions of each scheme. 

Interactions

A - Start/stop cumulative animation

B - Start/stop independent animation

S - Save image

metadata.name: Agave & Patchwork #244
metadata.description:
Agave & Patchwork
---------------
Controls:
Press 1-6 to change the scale of the canvas (1 = default, 2000px x 2000px, 6 = 12,000px x 12,000px)
S: Save output at current size
F: Toggle fullscreen
Add the url params x and y to set custom dimensions. For example, add &x=1500&y=500 for a 1500px x 500px image
---------------
Tyler Boswell (@teaboswell) 2023
CC BY-NC-ND 4.0, See bundle.js.LICENSE.txt for third party license information

metadata.name: Interlaced #203
metadata.description:
From African tribal clothes to Islamic mosaics every civilization throughout history has produced delicate patterns to share the essence of their culture. These artifacts have changed our understanding of how art, like societies form through bonds, the very fabric of things that have become symbols for cycles, paths and relationships.

Interlaced explores these unique motifs using emergent algorithms to produce colorful continuous patterns. The project uses a dynamic engine that traverses triangular meshes placing diverse tile configurations. By combining art with technology, the project aims to tell a new story of making digital connections between geography, culture and time.

Press “s” to save in high-resolution.

metadata.name: Fire Card #60
metadata.description:
Fire Cards is a series of generative artworks inspired by 19th-century Japanese fireworks catalogues. The images in these catalogues didn't so much focus on realism, but on the visual associations of the pyrotechnic effects instead. Using a restricted color palette and relatively simple shapes, this resulted in vibrant, graphical posters that sparked your own imagination more than anything else.

In Fire Cards, the abstract, static images are transformed back into lively, dynamic worlds again, each with their own distinctive, centuries-old aesthetics. Using a custom animation and 2D render system, the algorithmically generated worlds slowly build up and show a magical fireworks performance.

Fire Cards are tiny, personal and unique shows of wonder.

metadata.name: Paperwork #27
metadata.description:
[interactive]
chaos in order
experimental vintage series

press "SPACE" to show/hide grid
